title: The Trade Act 2021 (Power to Implement International Trade Agreements) (Extension to Expiry) Regulations 2025
The Customs Tariff (Establishment) (EU Exit) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
The Export Control (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
The Charities Act 2022 (Commencement No. 4 and Saving Provision) Regulations 2025
summary: The 2025 regulations introduce a streamlined process for charities to make small payments driven by moral obligations—without needing prior approval from regulators or courts—as long as they meet clear legal tests. From November 2025, charity trustees can approve these payments directly, with the maximum amount tied to the charity’s annual income (making larger charities more flexible). A separate change clarifies that decisions on such payments can be handled by others, not just trustees, though trustees remain accountable. Museums and galleries remain barred from removing certain collection items, preserving existing safeguards. These changes aim to reduce bureaucracy while ensuring responsible financial use, potentially speeding up support for vulnerable individuals or public services in urgent need.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Windsor) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
The Education (Inspectors of Education and Training in Wales) Order 2025
summary: This law names specific individuals as official overseers responsible for monitoring education and training standards in Wales, enabling them to ensure quality and accountability across schools, colleges, and vocational programs. Their role includes identifying gaps in compliance, driving improvements, and reporting findings to support better outcomes for learners and educators.

title: The Control of Mercury (Enforcement) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: The UK’s mercury regulations now bar importing and exporting dental amalgam, with customs officers empowered to enforce these restrictions. It also adds new EU mercury controls—covering products like dental fillings—to the list of enforceable rules, tightening oversight of mercury use to protect human health and the environment. No major business costs are anticipated.

title: The Senedd Cymru (Disqualification) Order 2025 / Gorchymyn Senedd Cymru (Anghymhwyso) 2025
summary: This law changes which jobs prevent someone from becoming a member of the Welsh Parliament (Senedd Cymru) starting in elections held on or after April 6, 2026. People holding certain offices listed in the Schedule (like specific public roles) will no longer be allowed to serve as elected members, though they can still run as candidates. It replaces previous rules from 2020, which will only apply to elections before April 2026. The change aims to separate elected roles from other positions to ensure independence in Parliament.

title: The Financial Services (Gibraltar) (Amendment) (EU Exit) Regulations 2025
summary: The UK has extended for one more year a temporary agreement allowing Gibraltar-based financial firms to continue serving UK customers and enabling UK firms to operate in Gibraltar's market. This gives both sides more time to adjust to post-Brexit rules without disrupting existing services or requiring immediate compliance changes. No major economic effects are expected, but details on the minimal impact are available for transparency.

title: The Civil Enforcement of Parking Contraventions (County of East Sussex) (Amendment), Bus Lane Contraventions (Approved Local Authorities) (Amendment) and Moving Traffic Contraventions Designation Order 2025
The Criminal Justice Act 2003 (Removal of Prisoners for Deportation) Order 2025
The A1 in Northumberland: Morpeth to Ellingham Development Consent (Revocation) Order 2025
The Inspectors of Education, Children’s Services and Skills (No. 4) Order 2025
The East Sussex County Council (Exceat Bridge Replacement – A259 Eastbourne Road) Bridge Scheme 2023 Confirmation Instrument 2025
summary: A new law allows East Sussex County Council to replace Exceat Bridge on the A259 Eastbourne Road with a single-span bridge over the Cuckmere River. This change aims to improve navigation for boats by creating a wider, unobstructed river passage while maintaining road access. The project in Cuckmere Valley and Sutton with Seaford parishes may temporarily disrupt local traffic during construction but will modernize a critical transport link for drivers and river users.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Windsor Great Park) (Restricted Area EG R161) Regulations 2025
The Stonestreet Green Solar Order 2025
The Access to the Countryside (Coastal Margin) (Portsmouth to South Hayling) Order 2025
The Energy Act 2023 (Commencement No. 4) Regulations 2025
The Nuclear Installations (Prescribed Conditions and Excepted Matter) Regulations 2025
summary: This law adds certain nuclear waste disposal sites to the UK’s liability framework but also creates a simplified process to exempt low-risk sites from it. Previously, only nuclear power plants were covered under the Nuclear Installations Act 1965. The updated regime now includes disposal sites, holding their operators strictly liable (up to a legal cap) for accidents and requiring them to secure approved funds. However, if a site meets four specific safety conditions—like operating under strict permits, having a safe history, posing low radiation risks, and avoiding criticality hazards—it can be classified as an "excluded disposal site," removing its liability under the regime. This ensures operators of other nuclear facilities (e.g., power plants) aren’t held responsible for waste disposed of at such exempt sites. The change aligns the UK with international nuclear safety standards while reducing compliance costs for qualifying low-risk disposal sites.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Huntingdon Station) (Emergency) (Revocation) Regulations 2025
The Construction Products (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This law updates UK rules so builders and traders can keep using CE-marked construction products (like windows or insulation) if they meet the latest EU safety standards introduced in late 2024. It ensures products sold in the UK under these new EU rules remain legal, gives trading standards clear authority to crack down on unsafe imports, and stops builders having to redo certifications for compliant materials—keeping renovations and new builds moving without delay while maintaining fire safety and structural integrity checks.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Alrewas) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
The Phytosanitary Conditions (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
The Diocese of Leeds (Educational Endowments) (Horton in Ribblesdale Church of England School) Order 2025
The National Health Service (Help with Health Costs) (Miscellaneous Amendments) Regulations 2025
summary: These changes make three key updates to NHS healthcare cost rules in England. First, patients getting NHS treatment for tuberculosis (TB) or related issues won’t pay prescription charges for those drugs. Second, cancer patients who buy prescription prepayment certificates will now automatically get refunds if they qualify for exemptions, fixing a previous oversight. Refund values for these certificates have also increased slightly to match updated prices (£32.05 for 3 months, £114.50 for 12 months). Third, people evacuated to the UK for medical care from conflict zones can be granted temporary access to the NHS Low Income Scheme, helping them cover costs like travel, prescriptions, or dental and optical care for a limited period.

title: The Victims and Prisoners Act 2024 (Commencement No. 8) Regulations 2025
The A122 (Lower Thames Crossing) Development Consent (Amendment) (No. 2) Order 2025
The Official Controls (Import of High-Risk Food and Feed of Non-Animal Origin) (Amendment of Commission Implementing Regulation (EU) 2019/1793) (England) Regulations 2025
summary: These regulations update the list of high-risk non-animal food and feed imports requiring increased scrutiny at UK borders, replacing outdated EU tariff codes with the UK’s simplified commodity codes. They add or remove specific products based on contamination risks, adjust how frequently checks occur, and streamline requirements for labs testing for pesticides. This aligns oversight with post-Brexit systems, reducing administrative complexity for border agencies and importers while maintaining food safety standards. Updated guidelines and documents are available online or through the Food Standards Agency.

title: The Oxford Street Development Corporation (Establishment) Order 2025
The A122 (Lower Thames Crossing) Development Consent (Amendment) Order 2025
The Customs Tariff (Preferential Trade Arrangements) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: UK businesses exporting goods to South Korea can now include EU-made parts when claiming tariff-free or reduced-tariff access under the UK-Korea trade deal. This update, agreed in October 2025, means products using materials sourced from both the UK and EU (like UK-assembled cars with German components) will qualify as 'UK-originating' for Korean customs, cutting import costs for exporters and making UK goods more competitive in the Korean market.

title: The Companies (Directors’ Report) (Payment Reporting) Regulations 2025
The Financial Services and Markets Act 2000 (Regulated Activities etc.) (Amendment) (No. 2) Order 2025
The Employment Tribunals (Early Conciliation: Exemptions and Rules of Procedure) (Amendment) Regulations 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Birmingham) (No. 5) Regulations 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Huntingdon Station) (Emergency) Regulations 2025
The Economic Crime (Anti-Money Laundering) Levy (Amendment) Regulations 2025
summary: This law fixes confusion when businesses overpay the anti-money laundering levy: if HMRC took over collecting an unpaid levy from financial or gambling regulators, HMRC must now handle refunds for those overpayments. Businesses get faster, clear repayment routes instead of chasing multiple agencies, cutting red tape and ensuring they reclaim money owed within 30 days.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Portmoak, Tayside) (Emergency) (Revocation) Regulations 2025
The Aviation Safety (Amendment) Regulations 2025
The Wireless Telegraphy (Mobile Spectrum Trading) (Amendment) (No. 2) Regulations 2025
The Net Zero Teesside (Amendment) Order 2025
summary: This law lets the Net Zero Teesside carbon capture project make minor, agreed-upon adjustments to its original approved plans without undergoing a lengthy full re-approval process. It allows the project team to quickly fix small practical issues or update designs as construction progresses—like rerouting utility lines or adjusting site layouts—keeping the build on schedule. This speeds up delivery of facilities capturing industrial emissions from Teesside factories, directly supporting cleaner air and the UK’s target to remove millions of tonnes of carbon dioxide from the atmosphere annually.

title: The Income Tax (Pay As You Earn) (Amendment No. 2) Regulations 2025
summary: This change updates who counts as the tax authority by including both senior tax commissioners and frontline officers under the same definition. It gives top tax officials direct power to handle certain day-to-day tax collection tasks that were previously limited to officers only, making internal tax administration more flexible and speeding up how PAYE processes are managed without altering tax rules for workers or employers.

title: The Welfare Reform Act 2012 (Commencement No. 35) (Abolition of Benefits) Order 2025
summary: This law ends several legacy benefits starting in late 2025 to push all working-age people onto Universal Credit. By 1 December 2025, anyone receiving Employment and Support Allowance solely based on past National Insurance contributions (not income) loses their right to future income-related top-ups and is switched to the new-style allowance. From 1 April 2026, Income Support and Income-Based Jobseeker’s Allowance stop completely except for short transition periods—claimants must switch to Universal Credit by that date or lose payments. It also cuts off Housing Benefit for working-age people moving out of temporary or supported housing into regular accommodation after 14 November 2025, forcing them onto Universal Credit’s housing element instead. Missing these deadlines means immediate loss of support.

title: The Northern Ireland Troubles (Legacy and Reconciliation) Act 2023 (Commencement No. 2 and Transitional Provisions) (Amendment No. 2) Regulations 2025
summary: This law extends deadlines for investigations into historical Northern Ireland Troubles cases, giving official bodies until 30 April 2026—instead of 31 October 2025—to finalise reports and complete related work. It ensures investigators have more time to thoroughly examine complex cases involving past violence, directly impacting victims' families by delaying closure but aiming for more accurate, comprehensive findings. Public services handling these investigations gain critical breathing room to process evidence without rushing, supporting fairer outcomes for vulnerable individuals seeking truth about decades-old incidents.

title: The Financial Services (Overseas Recognition Regime Designations) Regulations 2025
summary: This law gives the UK Treasury power to approve foreign financial rules as matching UK standards, allowing British banks and firms to operate more easily in those countries. It lets ministers impose conditions—like requiring stricter oversight—or withdraw approval if standards slip, so deals with places like the EU, US or Singapore can happen faster while protecting UK markets. Regulators such as the Bank of England must supply needed advice, ensuring decisions are based on solid evidence to keep cross-border finance flowing securely for businesses and investors.

title: The Financial Services and Markets Act 2023 (Mutual Recognition Agreement) (Switzerland) Regulations 2025
The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Portmoak, Tayside) (Emergency) Regulations 2025
The M5 Junction 10 Development Consent (Correction) Order 2025
summary: This law revises the M5 Junction 10 Development Consent Order 2025 to fix mistakes and add missing details, following two formal requests under the Planning Act 2008. The changes ensure the project’s rules are accurate and legally compliant, which could affect how infrastructure improvements are implemented, such as road expansions or local traffic management, and ensure developers adhere to updated regulations.

title: The Football Governance Act 2025 (Commencement No. 1) Regulations 2025
summary: Starting 1 November 2025, these rules activate key powers for the new Independent Football Regulator. It lets regulators demand documents and information directly from football clubs to investigate finances or ownership, requires expert reports assessing club stability, and shields sensitive conversations during investigations from public disclosure. Clubs must now comply with these probes, giving the regulator real authority to tackle financial mismanagement and protect fans.

title: The Air Navigation (Restriction of Flying) (Bentley, South Yorkshire) (Emergency) Regulations 2025
